00001 # QuEST
00002 
00003 ## Versions
00004 
00005 QuEST is currently in prerelease and may be unstable.  
00006 
00007 Latest version: [0.11.1](https://github.com/aniabrown/QuEST/releases/tag/v0.11.1) 
00008 
00009 Please report errors or feedback to anna.brown@oerc.ox.ac.uk 
00010 
00011 ## Quick Start
00012 
00013 Copy or clone this repository to your machine. 
00014 
00015 In the root directory, compile using
00016 
00017 ```
00018 make
00019 ```
00020 
00021 Run an [example circuit file](tutorialExample.c) using
00022 
00023 ```
00024 ./demo
00025 ```
00026 
00027 The program will print information about your execution environment and some simple operations on a three qubit system. See the [tutorial](examples/tutorial.md) for more information. 
00028 
00029 
00030 ## Introduction
00031 
00032 The **Quantum Exact Simulation Toolkit** is a high performance simulator of universal quantum circuits. QuEST is written in C, hybridises OpenMP and MPI, and can run on a GPU. Needing only compilation, QuEST is easy to run both on laptops and supercomputers, where it can take advantage of multicore and networked machines to quickly simulate circuits on many qubits.
00033 
00034 > The GPU version of QuEST is currently located in another repository [here](https://github.com/aniabrown/QuEST_GPU), though the introduction in [examples/tutorial.md](/examples/tutorial.md) is still relevant.
00035 
00036 QuEST has a simple interface, independent of its run environment (on CPUs, GPUs or over networks),
00037 ```C
00038 hadamard(qubits, 0);
00039 
00040 controlledNot(qubits, 0, 1);
00041 
00042 rotateY(qubits, 0, .1);
00043 ```
00044 though is flexible
00045 ```C
00046 Vector v;
00047 v.x = 1; v.y = 0; v.z = 0;
00048 rotateAroundAxis(qubits, 0, 3.14/2, v);
00049 ```
00050 and powerful
00051 ```C
00052 ComplexMatrix2 u;
00053 u.r0c0 = (Complex) {.real=.5, .imag= .5};
00054 u.r0c1 = (Complex) {.real=.5, .imag=-.5}; 
00055 u.r1c0 = (Complex) {.real=.5, .imag=-.5};
00056 u.r1c1 = (Complex) {.real=.5, .imag= .5};
00057 unitary(qubits, 0, u);
00058 
00059 int[] controls = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
00060 multiControlledUnitary(qureg, controls, 5, 0, u);
00061 ```
00062 
00063 ## Getting started
00064 
00065 QuEST is contained entirely in the `.c` and `.h` files in the `QuEST/` folder. To use QuEST, copy these files to your computer and include `QuEST.h` in your C code. We include make files for compiling QuEST, and submission scripts for using QuEST with SLURM and PBS. See [examples/tutorial.md](/examples/tutorial.md) for an introduction. Clone or download this entire repository to include all examples as well as tests and documentation. 
00066 
00067 ## API Documentation
00068 
00069 View the API [here](https://aniabrown.github.io/QuEST/QuEST_8h.html), and the full documentation at https://aniabrown.github.io/QuEST/
00070 
00071 > For developers: To recreate the full documentation after making changes to the code, run doxygen doxyconf in the root directory. This will generate documentation in Doxygen_doc/html, and can be accessed through index.html in that folder. 
00072 
00073 ## Acknowledgements
00074 
00075 QuEST uses the [mt19937ar](http://www.math.sci.hiroshima-u.ac.jp/~m-mat/MT/MT2002/emt19937ar.html) Mersenne Twister algorithm for random number generation, under the BSD licence.
